interconnection.net_metering_details: New Hampshire has net metering for systems up to 1 MW. Credits at full retail rate for the first 100 kW. Eversource and Liberty Utilities are the major utilities. Monthly rollover, annual true-up. Group net metering allowed for community solar.

special_considerations.hoa_restrictions: New Hampshire has a solar access law (RSA 477:49). HOAs cannot prohibit solar installations. Restrictions that significantly increase cost or decrease efficiency are void.
special_considerations.historic_districts: Historic districts in Portsmouth, Concord, and other New England towns. NH Division of Historical Resources reviews solar in National Register districts.
special_considerations.wind_load_requirements: Mount Washington area has extreme wind requirements. Coastal areas 100-120 mph design wind speeds. Most of the state standard IBC.
special_considerations.snow_load_requirements: Significant snow loads throughout the state (40-80 psf ground snow load). White Mountains and northern areas have the highest requirements. Structural review commonly required.

licensing.license_type: Licensed electrician required for solar PV installations. Master or journeyman electrician license.

notes: New Hampshire has a moderate solar market supported by net metering and relatively high electricity rates. The state has a 25.2% RPS with a solar carve-out. No state income tax and no sales tax. Renewable Energy Certificates (RECs) provide additional revenue. Property tax exemption available for solar. Snow loads are a significant engineering consideration. Community solar through group net metering is available.
